title: 111_hr3703
content:
The Act may be cited as the "White House Conference on Autism Act of 2009". It includes findings related to autism. The Congress finds that Autism Spectrum Disorders (ASD) are the fastest-growing serious developmental disability in the U.S., affecting all racial, ethnic, and socioeconomic groups. The rate of autism in the United States has increased from 1 in 10,000 in the 1980s to 1 in 150 currently, indicating an epidemic. New cases of autism are diagnosed approximately every 20 minutes, with no signs of the epidemic slowing down. The epidemic of autism continues to grow rapidly, with a new case diagnosed every 20 minutes. More children will be diagnosed with autism this year than with AIDS, diabetes, and cancer combined, costing the nation over $35 billion annually. The educational, labor, housing, and medical communities are ill-equipped to handle the increasing number of individuals with autism. The autism epidemic is a threatening condition that could deprive the nation of future talent. Despite being an urgent societal concern, autism research receives minimal federal funding compared to other childhood diseases. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 allocated $1 billion for autism research, including studies on environmental factors, treatments, and early identification. A White House Conference on Autism aims to further advance research on cutting-edge treatments and services. The Combating Autism Act of 2006 allocated $1 billion for research on cutting-edge treatments and services for autism. SEC. 3. AUTHORIZATION OF THE CONFERENCE. The President is required to call the White House Conference on Autism by December 31, 2010, to make policy recommendations on combating autism in the US. The Secretaries of Health and Human Services, Education, and Housing and Urban Development will plan and conduct the Conference. The Co-chairs will plan and convene the Conference with the Surgeon General to galvanize a national effort to find the causes of autism, identify solutions for autistic individuals and families, and develop a comprehensive research agenda. The Co-chairs will bring together scientific minds to create a research agenda on environmental triggers for autism, engage parents and experts in a national dialogue on lifelong challenges, and showcase effective programs for autistic individuals. The legislation aims to review and improve existing programs at all levels to enhance the well-being of autistic individuals and their families. SEC. 4. POLICY COMMITTEE; RELATED COMMITTEES. Established by June 30, 2009, the Policy Committee consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House, including individuals with experience in addressing the needs of people with autism spectrum disorders in the United States. The Policy Committee in the United States consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House, with specific selection processes for House and Senate appointees. The Policy Committee in the United States consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House, with specific selection processes for House and Senate appointees. Senate appointees are selected by the majority and minority leaders of the Senate after consultation with relevant committees. The Policy Committee in the United States consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House. Two members are selected by the minority leader of the Senate, with specific qualifications required for certain appointees, including knowledge about autism intervention programs and being a parent or legal guardian of individuals with autism. The Policy Committee in the United States consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House, with specific qualifications required for certain appointees, including knowledge about autism intervention programs and being a parent or legal guardian of individuals with autism. Other members must be knowledgeable about autism intervention programs, educational and housing needs, and training for law enforcement. The Policy Committee in the United States consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House, with specific qualifications required for certain appointees. Members must have knowledge about autism intervention programs, educational and housing needs, and training for law enforcement. The Committee acts by majority vote, with a quorum required for conducting business. The Policy Committee in the United States consists of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House, with specific qualifications required for certain appointees. A quorum of Committee members is needed to conduct business. The Surgeon General serves as the chairperson and can only vote to break a tie. The Committee must meet within 30 days of the last member selection and subsequent meetings are called by the chairperson for discussions and decision-making. The Policy Committee, consisting of 17 members appointed by the President and the Speaker of the House, meets at the call of the chairperson to make recommendations for the timely convening of the Conference, propose an agenda within 90 days, suggest delegates, determine the number of delegates, and establish an executive committee of 3 members. The Policy Committee, with 17 members appointed by the President and Speaker of the House, recommends timely Conference convening, proposes agenda within 90 days, suggests delegates, determines delegate number, and forms a 3-member executive committee. The Conference establishes the number of delegates and an executive committee with 3 members of the Policy Committee. SEC. 5. CONFERENCE DELEGATES.

The Cochairs will gather delegates from various backgrounds related to autism and neurodevelopmental disorders, including government representatives, professionals, laypeople, and members of the public affected by autism spectrum disorders in the United States.

SEC. 6. CONFERENCE ADMINISTRATION. In administering this section, the Cochairs shall provide written notice to all members of the Policy Committee of each meeting, request cooperation from other Federal departments, and make a proposed agenda available for public comment. The Policy Committee, prepared by the Cochairs, will address major issues in autism, provide necessary background materials, and hire additional personnel as needed without following standard appointment procedures. The Cochairs will ensure that the proposed agenda is published in the Federal Register within 30 days of approval by the Policy Committee, and that personnel employed are balanced in terms of represented points of views. The Policy Committee approves the agenda, ensures personnel balance in terms of viewpoints, and appoints without political affiliation. Recommendations are independent of influence, based on collective judgment. Statistical data must be current and adequate before the Conference is convened. Before the Conference is convened, the Cochairs must ensure that current and adequate statistical data and other information on autism spectrum disorders in the United States are readily available to the delegates. This information is necessary to evaluate Federal programs and policies related to autism spectrum disorders. The Cochairs may accept gifts (cash or in kind) on behalf of the United States to carry out the Act. Records must be maintained regarding the sources, amounts, and uses of gifts accepted. The Cochairs must maintain records of the sources, amounts, and uses of gifts accepted under the Act, as well as the identity of recipients and the amount of assistance received by each person. SEC. 7. REPORT OF THE CONFERENCE. The Policy Committee must prepare a preliminary report on the Conference within 100 days of adjournment, to be published in the Federal Register and sent to state CEOs. States must submit their views within 45 days. A final report, including chief executives' views, must be prepared within 6 months of adjournment. After the Conference adjourns, the Policy Committee will prepare a final report including the views of state chief executive officers and recommendations for administrative action and legislation. This report will be published in the Federal Register and sent to the President and Congress. SEC. 8. STATUS REPORTS. The Surgeon General must provide an initial status report within 2 years of the Conference adjournment, documenting the implementation of recommendations. Subsequent status reports are required every 5 years until all recommendations are achieved, as mandated by the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General must prepare and publish a status report every 5 years after the Conference adjourns until all recommendations are implemented. The report will document the implementation of recommendations and will be transmitted to the President and Congress. The term "State" in this Act refers to several entities including States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the Virgin Islands, and the Northern Mariana Islands. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization is granted to appropriate necessary sums for the first fiscal year of planning the Conference by the Policy Committee, the following fiscal year, and the fiscal year in which the Conference is held. Any new spending authority or authority to enter into contracts under this Act is limited to the extent and amounts specified. The United States is obligated to make outlays as provided in appropriations Acts. Funds appropriated for this Act and gifts received shall remain available for 1 year after the Conference adjourns. Unobligated funds must be expended or obligated before expiration. Any unobligated funds from appropriations Acts and gifts received for the Act must be expended or obligated within 1 year after the Conference adjourns. If the Conference is not convened before December 31, 2010, a trust fund will be established for a future Conference on Autism.
